item.title: Tips of blog down
item.description:
• You can rearrange webpages within config.toml or config.yaml. For example:
menu:
  main:
    - name: "About"
      url: "/about/"
      weight: 0
    - name: "Blog"
      url: "/post/"
      weight: 1
    - name: "GitHub"
      url: "https://github.com/rstudio/blogdown"
      weight: 2
    - name: "Twitter"
      url: "https://twitter.com/rstudio"
      weight: 3
  • To create a single page, create a file (markdown or rmarkdown) within content folder. For example, if I want to add a page to introduce my research, create a file named research.Rmd within content folder (blogdown::new_content(path = "research.Rmd")). And then add it to the navigation. So the yaml seems like this now:
menu:
  main:
    - name: "About"
      url: "/about/"
      weight: 0
    - name: "Research"
      url: "/research/"
      weight: 1
    - name: "Blog"
      url: "/post/"
      weight: 2
    - name: "GitHub"
      url: "https://github.com/rstudio/blogdown"
      weight: 3
    - name: "Twitter"
      url: "https://twitter.com/rstudio"
      weight: 4

  • If you do not want to have the list of your post as the first view, create a file named as _index.md within the content folder. Put the information you want into that file. For example, you can just copy the about.md file and rename is as _index.md. Then it will be the first view of your website. People can still see your posts when they point the Blog head.

  • To create a new post, just use blogdown::new_post() or use the Addins of the Rstudio IDE.

  • You can create figure captions and cross-reference it back. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

  • The same as tables. See Table 1 for example:
knitr::kable(cars[1:6, ], booktabs = T, caption = "A table.")
Table 1: A table.
speed dist
4 2
4 10
7 4
7 22
8 16
9 10
  • Citations (Li 2016), see also Fenner (2012) for details. So basically, you should write all your papers within Rmarkdown now! Drop the MS Word.

References

Fenner, Martin. 2012. “One-Click Science Marketing.” Nature Materials 11 (4): 261–63. doi:10.1038/nmat3283.

Li, Daijiang. 2016. “Awesome Title” 11 (4). Nature Publishing Group: 261–63. doi:10.1038/nmat3283.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description:
This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are:

  1. You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r});
  2. A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.

There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown. For example, you can write a task list with Blackfriday but not with Pandoc:

  • Write an R package.
  • Write a book.
  • …
  • Profit!

Similarly, Blackfriday does not support LaTeX math and Pandoc does. I have added the MathJax support to this theme (hugo-lithium-theme) but there is a caveat for plain Markdown posts: you have to include inline math expressions in a pair of escaped parentheses \( \) instead of dollar signs $ $, e.g. \(S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\). For R Markdown posts, you can use $ $ to write inline math expressions.

When creating a new post, you have to decide whether the post format is Markdown or R Markdown, and this can be done via the rmd argument of the function blogdown::new_post(), e.g.

blogdown::new_post("Post Title", rmd = FALSE)

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.
